content: Verb conjugation in German is more complex and includes more variations based on tense, subject, and mood compared to English. In German, verbs change forms based on the grammatical person (first, second, or third), number (singular or plural), and tense (present, past, future). Additionally, German has six tenses compared to English's four (present, past, future, and present perfect). German also has several irregular verbs that have unique conjugation patterns that do not follow the regular rules. In contrast, English verb conjugation is simpler, with only one form for each person and number in the present tense and a few irregular verbs to learn.
